title: US Open 2024 Day Ten Quarter Final Recap
description: The semi-final lineup at the 2024 US Open is set, and Jannik Sinner will take on Jack Draper in the top half, along with Taylor Fritz against Frances Tiafoe from the bottom section of the draw. In Wednesday’s two remaining quarter-finals, Jack Draper made light work of Alex de Minaur, pushing him aside 6-3, 7-5, …
author: Jonathan
excerpt: The semi-final lineup at the 2024 US Open is set, and Jannik Sinner will take on Jack Draper in the top half, along with Taylor Fritz against Frances Tiafoe from the bottom section of the draw. In Wed
text: The semi-final lineup at the 2024 US Open is set, and Jannik Sinner will take on Jack Draper in the top half, along with Taylor Fritz against Frances Tiafoe from the bottom section of the draw. In Wednesday’s two remaining quarter-finals, Jack Draper made light work of Alex de Minaur, pushing him aside 6-3, 7-5, 6-2 as the Aussie appeared to suffer a reoccurrence of the hip injury he sustained at Wimbledon. Pre-tournament favourite Jannik Sinner then delivered in the night session, proving too adept from the baseline to see off Daniil Medvedev  6-2, 1-6, 6-1, 6-4. Winner Loser Scoreline Jannik Sinner (1) Daniil Medvedev (5) 6-2 1-6 6-1 6-4 Jack Draper (25) Alex de Minaur (10) 603 7-5 6-2 Sinner Too Strong for Medvedev Jannik Sinner is the man to beat at this year’s US Open, and he brushed aside Daniil Medvedev 6-2, 1-6, 6-1, 6-4 to secure a spot in his third major semi-final of the season. The two have now met 13 times, with the H2H at 7-6 in Medvedev’s favour, although he’s only won 1 of the last seven matches. The latest encounter wasn’t a match for the ages. Neither player was brilliant, and momentum switched frequently. Sinner surged ahead with a double-break lead in the first set before Medvedev, after a shaky start, started to find his game as he captured the second. However, the match always felt like Sinner could take his game up a notch to leave Medvedev reeling, and that happened when he won the first five games of the third set, taking control of the match. In the fourth set, Sinner’s level dropped briefly, allowing Medvedev a sniff, but the Italian saved two critical break points at 2-3. He then secured a decisive break and converted his second match point on his serve. Overall, Medvedev never looked like he could win this one, and I thought Sinner, despite not being at his best, had the measure of his opponent. I liked that he threw in some serve-and-volley plays and drop shots to mix it up and I think he wins the title comfortably. It was very tough. We know each other quite well. We played in Australia this year and then London. We knew it was going to be very physical. The first two sets were strange because whoever made the first break then started to roll. We tried to work hard on this aspect of the game. I know I can improve a lot, especially going to the net. I tried to serve and volley several times, trying to mix something in. I’m very happy with how I did today, and let’s see how I handle the next opponent. Sinner on his win. Match Stats   Jannik Sinner Daniil Medvedev Aces 4 5 Double Faults 1 6 1st Serve Percentage 53% 56% 1st Serve Points Won 76% (39/51) 67% (41/61) 2nd Serve Points Won 61% (28/46) 42% (20/48) Break Points Saved 75% (6/8) 67% (10/15) 1st Return Points Won 33% (20/61) 24% (12/51) 2nd Return Points Won 58% (28/48) 39% (18/46) Break Points Converted 33% (5/15) 25% (2/8) Winners 31 30 Unforced Errors 38 57 Net Points Won 85% (28/33) 67% (16/24) Max Points In Row 11 5 Service Points Won 69% (67/97) 56% (61/109) Return Points Won 44% (48/109) 31% (30/97) Total Points Won 56% (115/206) 44% (91/206) Max Games In Row 5 5 Service Games Won 88% (14/16) 69% (11/16) Return Games Won 31% (5/16) 13% (2/16) Total Games Won 59% (19/32) 41% (13/32) Highlights Draper Denies De Minaur With Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic both in the bottom half of the draw, Jack Draper is an unlikely semi-finalist, but he’s there without dropping a set, his latest win being a routine 6-3, 7-5, 6-2 victory over Alex de Minaur. Draper has a powerful baseline game, backed up with a heavy lefty serve, but has shown some stamina issues in the past. Based on that, I thought De Minaur would ensure he was out there for 4+ hours before eventually running him into the ground. However, the Aussie, who hadn’t played since a hip injury at Wimbledon, appeared to aggravate that injury during the first set. By that point, he was already down a break, and the tone of the match had been set. If the Demon can’t run, he cannot win, as his game is built on court coverage. Draper, on the other hand, who also received treatment for a leg issue, can blaze winners, and once he’d got in front, he barely looked back. Despite losing a  4-2 lead in the second set, he was soon back on track with a decisive break in the 11th game and easily clinched the third set, dropping only six points on serve. I think I played a solid match. I feel the best fitness-wise that I’ve been in a long time, and I think that is where Alex has sort of got me in the past. I also think he was maybe struggling a little bit today with something, which might have helped me a little bit. But credit to Alex. He’s an amazing fighter and an unbelievable player. We’re going to have many more battles to come. Draper on his win. Alongside playing the sport, I also enjoy writing about the tour, rackets, strings, and the technicalities of the game. Whether it's breaking down the latest tournament results or discussing the latest gear innovations, I'm always eager to share my insights with fellow tennis enthusiasts.
html:
The semi-final lineup at the 2024 US Open is set, and Jannik Sinner will take on Jack Draper in the top half, along with Taylor Fritz against Frances Tiafoe from the bottom section of the draw.

In Wednesday’s two remaining quarter-finals, Jack Draper made light work of Alex de Minaur, pushing him aside 6-3, 7-5, 6-2 as the Aussie appeared to suffer a reoccurrence of the hip injury he sustained at Wimbledon.

Pre-tournament favourite Jannik Sinner then delivered in the night session, proving too adept from the baseline to see off Daniil Medvedev  6-2, 1-6, 6-1, 6-4.

Winner Loser Scoreline
Jannik Sinner (1) Daniil Medvedev (5) 6-2 1-6 6-1 6-4
Jack Draper (25) Alex de Minaur (10) 603 7-5 6-2

Sinner Too Strong for Medvedev

Jannik Sinner is the man to beat at this year’s US Open, and he brushed aside Daniil Medvedev 6-2, 1-6, 6-1, 6-4 to secure a spot in his third major semi-final of the season.

The two have now met 13 times, with the H2H at 7-6 in Medvedev’s favour, although he’s only won 1 of the last seven matches.

The latest encounter wasn’t a match for the ages. Neither player was brilliant, and momentum switched frequently.

Sinner surged ahead with a double-break lead in the first set before Medvedev, after a shaky start, started to find his game as he captured the second.

However, the match always felt like Sinner could take his game up a notch to leave Medvedev reeling, and that happened when he won the first five games of the third set, taking control of the match.

In the fourth set, Sinner’s level dropped briefly, allowing Medvedev a sniff, but the Italian saved two critical break points at 2-3. He then secured a decisive break and converted his second match point on his serve.

Overall, Medvedev never looked like he could win this one, and I thought Sinner, despite not being at his best, had the measure of his opponent. I liked that he threw in some serve-and-volley plays and drop shots to mix it up and I think he wins the title comfortably.

It was very tough. We know each other quite well. We played in Australia this year and then London. We knew it was going to be very physical. The first two sets were strange because whoever made the first break then started to roll. We tried to work hard on this aspect of the game. I know I can improve a lot, especially going to the net. I tried to serve and volley several times, trying to mix something in. I’m very happy with how I did today, and let’s see how I handle the next opponent. Sinner on his win.

Match Stats

  Jannik Sinner Daniil Medvedev
Aces 4 5
Double Faults 1 6
1st Serve Percentage 53% 56%
1st Serve Points Won 76% (39/51) 67% (41/61)
2nd Serve Points Won 61% (28/46) 42% (20/48)
Break Points Saved 75% (6/8) 67% (10/15)
1st Return Points Won 33% (20/61) 24% (12/51)
2nd Return Points Won 58% (28/48) 39% (18/46)
Break Points Converted 33% (5/15) 25% (2/8)
Winners 31 30
Unforced Errors 38 57
Net Points Won 85% (28/33) 67% (16/24)
Max Points In Row 11 5
Service Points Won 69% (67/97) 56% (61/109)
Return Points Won 44% (48/109) 31% (30/97)
Total Points Won 56% (115/206) 44% (91/206)
Max Games In Row 5 5
Service Games Won 88% (14/16) 69% (11/16)
Return Games Won 31% (5/16) 13% (2/16)
Total Games Won 59% (19/32) 41% (13/32)

Highlights

Draper Denies De Minaur

With Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic both in the bottom half of the draw, Jack Draper is an unlikely semi-finalist, but he’s there without dropping a set, his latest win being a routine 6-3, 7-5, 6-2 victory over Alex de Minaur.

Draper has a powerful baseline game, backed up with a heavy lefty serve, but has shown some stamina issues in the past.

Based on that, I thought De Minaur would ensure he was out there for 4+ hours before eventually running him into the ground.

However, the Aussie, who hadn’t played since a hip injury at Wimbledon, appeared to aggravate that injury during the first set.

By that point, he was already down a break, and the tone of the match had been set. If the Demon can’t run, he cannot win, as his game is built on court coverage.

Draper, on the other hand, who also received treatment for a leg issue, can blaze winners, and once he’d got in front, he barely looked back.

Despite losing a  4-2 lead in the second set, he was soon back on track with a decisive break in the 11th game and easily clinched the third set, dropping only six points on serve.

I think I played a solid match. I feel the best fitness-wise that I’ve been in a long time, and I think that is where Alex has sort of got me in the past. I also think he was maybe struggling a little bit today with something, which might have helped me a little bit. But credit to Alex. He’s an amazing fighter and an unbelievable player. We’re going to have many more battles to come. Draper on his win.
